thread.title: Struck by lightning as 'dangerous' thunderstorms hit Sydney | Stuff.co.nz
thread.title_full: Struck by lightning as 'dangerous' thunderstorms hit Sydney | Stuff.co.nz

title: Struck by lightning as 'dangerous' thunderstorms hit Sydney | Stuff.co.nz
text:
Struck by lightning as 'dangerous' thunderstorms hit Sydney Last updated 20:01, February 18 2017 TWITTER/NICK MOIR 
Large hailstones fall in the area of Hornsby. Golf ball-sized chunks falling in Rouse Hill, Castle Hill, Londonderry and Kellyville. 
Three sisters have been reportedly hit by lightning as severe storms lashed the Australian city of Sydney for a second day. 
Thunderstorms moving in a south-easterly direction were hitting Sydney's northern suburbs on Saturday afternoon. 
Three sisters in their sixties were struck by lightning while they were sitting together on a bench in Corbett Gardens, south of the city, at 3.15pm (5.15pm NZT). Storms now lashing parts of #NSW , massive hail is falling in some areas. For storm assistance call the #NSWSES on 132500 #NSWRFS pic.twitter.com/r0Rzm0EKPA — NSW RFS (@NSWRFS) February 18, 2017 
Two of the women had been treated for shock, and one woman was expected to be airlifted to Sydney to be treated for severe burns. 
READ MORE: 
Earlier Australia's Bureau of Meteorology had issued severe storm warnings, saying the weather could be dangerous. BUREAU OF METEOROLOGY 
The storms at 6.10pm (NZT). 
Jordan Notara, a meteorologist at Australia's Bureau of Meteorology, expected this first storm cell, which originated in Sydney's north-west fringe, to move over coastal waters by 6pm (8pm NZT). 
"There have been really strong steering winds pushing the storm in, quit deep easterly winds have stretch it out all the way to the coast in some form." 
Hail had been reported in Sydney's north-west with golf ball-sized chunks falling in Rouse Hill, Castle Hill, Londonderry and Kellyville. — Nick Moir (@nampix) February 18, 2017 
There had also been reports of hailstones further east in Hornsby. Ad Feedback 
The Bureau of Meteorology was tracking another storm cell that had formed north-west of Sydney and was moving towards Wisemans Ferry, as well as multiple storms moving south-easterly towards the central coast and Newcastle. 
Following the significant damage caused by Friday's severe weather, about 8000 homes and businesses were still without power on Saturday morning, the majority of which were on central coast, a spokeswoman for Ausgrid said. Massive hail storm in Sydney, never seen anything like it! #Hail #Sydneystorm pic.twitter.com/38hYjKO1Cg — Carla Sindel (@CarlsCarla) February 18, 2017 
Pockets of Palm Beach and Avalon would likely be without power until Sunday, while small numbers of residences and businesses on the central coast would have to wait until Monday to turn on the lights. 
Sunday was expected to be mostly dry and overcast, except for possible showers and storms in Sydney's north. - Sydney Morning Herald
